title: R41839
content: The Dodd-Frank Act established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) within the Federal Reserve System, consolidating regulatory authority in one regulator for consumer financial products and services. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has jurisdiction over various consumer financial products and services, serving as the primary federal supervisor for institutions offering these services. It can prescribe regulations for implementing federal consumer laws like the Truth in Lending Act and the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) oversees consumer financial products and services, enforcing laws like the Truth in Lending Act and the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act. Some of the Bureau's powers took effect when Dodd-Frank was signed in 2010, with the rest set to go into effect on the designated transfer date of July 21, 2011. The designated transfer date for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) is currently set for July 21, 2011. The Bureau's powers are dependent on the appointment of a Director by the President and Senate confirmation.
